questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerves does not have a nucleus associated with special visceral afferent (SVA) fibers?
questions.solution:
Trochlear nerve (CN IV) is a purely motor nerve that does not carry any sensory fibers. It innervates the superior oblique muscle of the eye and is associated with general somatic efferent (GSE) function.

Special Visceral Afferent (SVA):

  • Includes neurons in the seventh, ninth, and tenth cranial nerves.
  • These are associated with specialized receptors for taste.
  • Also includes the first cranial nerve.
  • Dendritic zones of the first cranial nerve are located in the caudal nasal mucosa for olfaction (sense of smell).

Explanation of other options:

Facial nerve (Option A) (cranial nerve VII) carries taste sensations from the front two-thirds of the tongue to the nucleus solitarius, part of the special visceral afferent (SVA) column.

Vagus nerve (Option C) (cranial nerve X) carries taste sensations from the epiglottis and lower pharynx to the nucleus solitarius, part of the special visceral afferent (SVA) column.

Glossopharyngeal nerve (Option D) (cranial nerve IX) transmits taste sensations from the back one-third of the tongue to the nucleus solitarius via the special visceral afferent (SVA) column.

Reference: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/neuroscience/special-somatic-afferent

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470353/#

questions.text: During which developmental week does the human heart begin to beat?
questions.solution:
The heart begins to beat at approximately 21 days of gestation, which corresponds to the 4th week of development.

Development of Heart:

questions.text: Which of the following arteries does not contribute to the blood supply of the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the image is the right ventricle (RV). It is mainly supplied by branches of the right coronary artery, including the acute marginal artery, as well as contributions from the anterior interventricular artery (a branch of the LAD). In contrast, the diagonal artery, also arising from the LAD mainly supplies the anterolateral portion of the left ventricle.

Coronary Artery Supply:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a boundary of the Calot's triangle?
questions.solution:
The gallbladder is not a boundary of Calot's triangle, which is formed by the cystic duct, common hepatic duct, and the inferior surface of the liver.

Calot's Triangle:

  • Also known as hepatobiliary triangle or hepatocystic triangle.
  • Located near the porta hepatis.
  • Surgically important during cholecystectomy.
  • Dissection of this area helps identify cystic artery and cystic duct before ligation to avoid injury.
  • Boundaries:
    • Lateral: Cystic duct.
    • Medial: Common hepatic duct.
    • Superior: Inferior surface of the liver.
  • Contents:
    • Cystic artery
    • Right hepatic artery
    • Cystic lymph node (node of Lund)
    • Connective tissue
    • Lymphatics

Reference:

https://radiopaedia.org/articles/hepatocystic-triangle-1

questions.text: Which nerve injury most commonly results in foot drop?
questions.solution:
Foot drop is typically caused by injury to the common peroneal (fibular) nerve.

Lesions of the Common Fibular Nerve:

  • Common fibular nerve is superficially located as it winds around the neck of the fibula, making it susceptible to injury.
  • Causes of Injury:
    • Compression:
      • From plaster casts, tight bandages, or ganglia at the fibular neck.
    • Entrapment:
      • Beneath fibularis longus within the "fibular tunnel" formed by attachments of fibularis longus to the fibular head and shaft.
    • Traction Injury:
      • Associated with knee dislocations or avulsion injuries of the biceps femoris insertion and fibular head.
    • Torsional Injury:
      • Can follow ankle sprains or fractures, with force transmitted up via the interosseous membrane to the proximal leg.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Motor Deficits (Foot Drop):
      • Weakness/paralysis of ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension, and foot eversion.
      • Inversion and plantarflexion are preserved.
    • Sensory Loss:
      • Diminished sensation over the dorsum of the foot, especially in the first dorsal web space.
    • Reflexes:
      • Ankle reflex remains intact.

Explanation of other options:

Femoral nerve (Option B): Lesions of the femoral nerve lead to weakness in knee extension due to quadriceps involvement and cause sensory loss in the anterior and medial thigh. However, dorsiflexion of the foot remains intact, so foot drop does not occur.

Tibial nerve (Option C) injury affects plantarflexion, inversion, and toe flexion. It can cause heel pain or burning sensations in the sole, but it does not result in foot drop since dorsiflexors are spared.

Sciatic nerve (Option D): Although the sciatic nerve supplies all muscles below the knee, complete palsy is rare. When affected, it usually involves the common peroneal division, which causes foot drop. Hence, the primary culprit is still the common peroneal nerve, not the sciatic nerve directly.

choices.text: From the dorsal rami of C1

questions.text: Which nerve supplies the muscle indicated by the arrow in the given image?
questions.solution:
The levator scapulae muscle is primarily innervated by the dorsal scapular nerve (C5), with additional contributions from C3 and C4 spinal nerves. The dorsal scapular nerve arises from the C5 root of the brachial plexus and also supplies the rhomboid major and minor muscles. Function: Elevates the scapula and assists in downward rotation.



Explanation of other options:

Suprascapular nerve (option B): Innervates supraspinatus and infraspinatus, not the levator scapulae. Arises from the upper trunk (C5-C6) of the brachial plexus.

From the dorsal rami of C1 (option C): C1 dorsal ramus contributes to the suboccipital nerve, which innervates suboccipital muscles, not the levator scapulae.

Subscapular nerve (option D): The upper and lower subscapular nerves (from C5-C6) supply the subscapularis and teres major, not the levator scapulae.

questions.text: A mass originating from the uncinate process of the pancreas is most likely to compress which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
The uncinate process of the pancreas is a small, hook-like projection from the head of the pancreas that extends posteriorly and inferiorly, wrapping around the superior mesenteric vessels (SMA and SMV).

A tumor in this region is likely to compress or invade the superior mesenteric artery (SMA), which supplies blood to the midgut (small intestine and proximal colon).

Nutcracker Syndrome:


  • A condition caused by compression of the left renal vein leading to the left renal vein hypertension.
  • Highlights the anatomical relationship between the pancreas, veins, and aorta.

Pancreas' Role in Nutcracker Syndrome:

  • Positioned directly in front of the compression site, anterior to the SMA.
  • Proximity to vascular structures suggests the potential to worsen the condition.
  • The uncinate process being close to the superior mesenteric artery and vein further emphasises the pancreas's proximity to major vessels.

Explanation of other options:

Portal vein (option B): Formed by the union of the superior mesenteric vein (SMV) and splenic vein, located posterior to the neck of the pancreas. The uncinate process is inferior, so it typically does not directly compress the portal vein.

Common hepatic artery (option C): Arises from the celiac trunk and gives rise to the proper hepatic artery and gastroduodenal artery. It runs superior to the pancreas and is not typically affected by tumors of the uncinate process.

Inferior mesenteric artery (option D): Arises from the abdominal aorta at a lower level, supplying the hindgut (distal colon and rectum). It is too distant from the uncinate process to be affected.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with unsteady gait, difficulty performing rapid alternating movements, and dysmetria on finger-to-nose testing. Which of the following arteries is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
The superior cerebellar artery (SCA) supplies the superior portion of the cerebellum and parts of the midbrain. Thrombosis or infarction in this vessel can lead to ataxia, intention tremor, dysdiadochokinesia, and other coordination deficits, due to cerebellar dysfunction.

Midbrain Blood Supply:

  • Anterior-Medial Supply: branches of the Basilar artery
  • Anterior-Lateral Supply: branches of the Posterior Choroidal arteries and Quadrigeminal artery from the Posterior Cerebral Artery
  • Posterior Supply: Quadrigeminal Artery and Superior Cerebellar Artery

Explanation of other options:

Posterior cerebral artery (PCA) (Option A): Incorrect because PCA infarcts primarily affect the occipital lobe, leading to visual deficits (e.g., homonymous hemianopia) rather than ataxia.

Middle cerebral artery (MCA) (Option B): Incorrect because MCA occlusion leads to contralateral motor and sensory deficits (especially in the face and upper limb) and aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved), but not significant ataxia.

Internal carotid artery (ICA) (Option C): Incorrect because ICA occlusion affects multiple territories, mainly causing hemiparesis, hemisensory loss, and aphasia rather than isolated cerebellar ataxia.

Reference:Neuroanatomy, Brainstem - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshel

The Midbrain - Colliculi - Peduncles - TeachMeAnatomy

choices.text: Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis longus
Abductor pollicis brevis and extensor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis brevis and extensor pollicis longus

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with pain and tenderness along the radial side of her wrist, especially aggravated by thumb movement. On examination the following test was positive. Inflammation of the tendon sheaths of which of the following muscle pairs is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms and a positive Finkelstein test are characteristic of De Quervain's tenosynovitis, which involves inflammation of the first dorsal extensor compartment of the wrist. This compartment contains the tendons of:

  • Abductor pollicis longus (APL)
  • Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)

Explanation of other options:

Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis longus (Option B): Extensor pollicis longus (EPL) is located in the third dorsal compartment and is not involved in De Quervain's tenosynovitis.

Abductor pollicis brevis and extensor pollicis brevis (Option C): Abductor pollicis brevis (APB) is part of the thenar muscles and does not pass through the first dorsal compartment.

Abductor pollicis brevis and extensor pollicis longus (Option D): Extensor pollicis longus (EPL) is not affected, and abductor pollicis brevis (APB) is a thenar muscle.

Reference:Finkelstein Sign - PubMed

Finkelstein Sign - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

choices.text: Right gastric and right gastroepiploic artery
Right gastric and left gastric artery
Right gastroepiploic and short gastric vessels
Right gastric and short gastric vessels

questions.text: A 55-year-old male undergoes surgery for pancreatic cancer. During the procedure, the common hepatic artery is accidentally ligated. Which of the following arteries is most likely to have its blood supply compromised as a result?
questions.solution:
The common hepatic artery, a branch of the celiac trunk, supplies:

  • The right gastric artery via the proper hepatic artery
  • The right gastroepiploic artery via the gastroduodenal artery

Ligation of the common hepatic artery will impair blood supply to:

  • Right gastric artery (supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach)
  • Right gastroepiploic artery (supplies the greater curvature of the stomach)

Explanation of other options:

Right gastric and left gastric artery (option B): The left gastric artery arises directly from the celiac trunk, so it will still receive blood despite common hepatic artery ligation.

Right gastroepiploic and short gastric vessels (option C): The right gastroepiploic artery comes from the gastroduodenal artery (a branch of the common hepatic artery) and will be affected. Short gastric arteries, however, arise from the splenic artery, which remains intact.

Right gastric and short gastric vessels (option D): The right gastric artery is affected. The short gastric vessels come from the splenic artery and remain unaffected.

Reference:

Accidental Hepatic Artery Ligation in Humans - PMC

questions.text: A patient who recently underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) using the great saphenous vein now complains of numbness and tingling along the inner aspect of the leg and foot. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
The saphenous nerve, a sensory branch of the femoral nerve (L3-L4), provides sensation to the medial leg and foot. Since it travels close to the great saphenous vein, it is vulnerable to injury during vein harvesting in CABG. Damage to this nerve causes sensory disturbances such as paresthesia and numbness along the inner leg and foot.


Explanation of other options:

Superficial peroneal nerve (option A) provides sensory innervation to the anterolateral lower leg and dorsum of the foot. Unlikely to be affected in CABG as it is located in the lateral compartment of the leg.

Femoral nerve (option C) provides motor innervation to the anterior thigh muscles and sensory innervation to the anterior and medial thigh. Injury would cause weakness of quadriceps and loss of knee jerk reflex, which is not described in the question.

Sural nerve (option D) provides sensory innervation to the lateral foot and posterolateral calf. Not involved in medial leg and foot sensation, making it an unlikely option.

questions.text: A patient experiences vision loss, and imaging reveals an aneurysm compressing the optic chiasma. Which artery is most likely responsible for this compression?
questions.solution:
The optic chiasma lies just above the anterior communicating artery within the suprasellar cistern. Aneurysms of the anterior communicating artery are among the most frequent intracranial aneurysms and can press on the optic chiasma, resulting in bitemporal hemianopia (loss of peripheral vision in both eyes). Such aneurysms often present with visual disturbances, headaches, and may cause subarachnoid hemorrhage if ruptured.


Explanation of other options:

Anterior choroidal artery (option B) arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies parts of the optic tract, lateral geniculate body, and posterior limb of the internal capsule. Aneurysms here are rare and typically cause contralateral motor deficits rather than optic chiasma compression.

Middle cerebral artery (option C) does not course near the optic chiasma. MCA aneurysms more commonly affect the lateral convexity of the brain, leading to contralateral hemiparesis, aphasia (dominant hemisphere), or neglect (non-dominant hemisphere).

Anterior cerebral artery (option D) courses superior to the optic chiasma, but aneurysms at this location usually do not cause direct compression. ACA infarcts more commonly lead to leg weakness (contralateral) due to involvement of the paracentral lobule.

Reference: Anterior Communicating Artery Aneurysm Related to Visual Symptoms - PMC

questions.text: Identify the type of papillae shown in the provided histological image?
questions.solution:
Circumvallate papillae are large, dome-shaped structures positioned near the back of the tongue, arranged in a V-shaped row just in front of the sulcus terminalis. They are characterized by deep surrounding grooves called trenches, which contain numerous taste buds crucial for taste sensation.

At the base of these trenches are Von Ebner's glands, which produce serous secretions to flush the taste buds.


Explanation of other options:

Fungiform papillae (option A) are scattered mostly over the anterior tongue, have a mushroom shape, and contain taste buds on their top surface but lack the trench-like structures.


Filiform papillae (option C) are the most abundant, slender and pointed, covering much of the tongue's surface. They do not have taste buds and primarily serve a mechanical role in handling food.


Foliate papillae (option D) appear as vertical folds on the lateral edges of the tongue and contain taste buds but are relatively underdeveloped in humans.

Reference: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Tongue Taste Buds - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: A middle-aged patient presents with persistent jaw swelling and unintended weight loss. Imaging suggests a tumor involving the submandibular gland, and surgical excision is planned. During the procedure, which nerve is at the greatest risk of being injured?
questions.solution:
The lingual nerve, a sensory branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3), travels in close proximity to the submandibular gland, particularly as it crosses beneath the submandibular duct in the floor of the mouth. Due to this anatomical relationship, it is highly vulnerable during surgical procedures involving the submandibular gland.

Functions affected if damaged:

  • Loss of general sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • Loss of taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue (as it carries fibres from the chorda tympani nerve, a branch of the facial nerve).
  • Possible decreased salivation (as chorda tympani also carries parasympathetic fibres to the submandibular and sublingual glands).

  • The lingual nerve arises from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve (V3) within the infratemporal fossa.
  • It descends and advances anteriorly, situated medial to the lateral pterygoid muscle and deep to the mandibular ramus.
  • Upon entering the floor of the mouth, it passes superficial to the hyoglossus muscle and beneath the submandibular duct.
  • The nerve loops below the duct, moving from lateral to medial, before traveling upwards.
  • It provides general sensory innervation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • Due to its close anatomical relationship with the submandibular gland and duct, the lingual nerve is at significant risk during surgical excision of the submandibular gland.

Explanation of other options:

Nerve to mylohyoid (option A) is the motor branch of the inferior alveolar nerve supplies the mylohyoid muscle and anterior digastric. Injury would affect floor-of-mouth muscles but not tongue sensation or taste.

Inferior alveolar nerve (option B) enters the mandibular foramen to supply the lower teeth and is not in close contact with the submandibular gland, making it less likely to be affected during gland excision.

Hypoglossal nerve (option D) innervates most tongue muscles but lies deeper and slightly more medial. Damage leads to motor deficits like tongue deviation, not sensory or taste loss.

Reference: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Lingual Nerve - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf.

questions.text: Identify the structure shown in the given histological image?
questions.solution:
• Pancreatic islet cells (islets of Langerhans) are groups of hormone-producing cells scattered throughout the exocrine tissue of the pancreas.
  • These endocrine clusters regulate blood sugar levels by releasing insulin, glucagon, and other hormones.
  • The cells appear as pale-staining, round or oval aggregates, distinct from the surrounding darker-stained acinar tissue.

Explanation of other options:

Lymph node (Option A):


Glomerulus (Option B):


Spleen (Option C):


Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7565096/

choices.text: Loss of sensation in the mucosa of nasopharynx
Loss of sensation in maxillary area of face
Loss of sensation in jaw area
Loss of sensation in scalp and nose

questions.text: A patient presents with numbness over the forehead and upper part of the nose. Imaging reveals damage to the nerve exiting the region indicated by the blue arrow in the image. What clinical deficit is most consistent with this lesion?
questions.solution:
The blue arrow in the given image likely marks the supraorbital foramen, through which the supraorbital nerve (a branch of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve, CN V1) passes. Lesioning this nerve would cause sensory loss in the scalp, forehead, and upper nose region.

Trigeminal Nerve (CN V) and its Branches:


Explanation of other options:

Loss of sensation in the mucosa of nasopharynx (Option A): Incorrect because this is supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), not the supraorbital nerve.

Loss of sensation in maxillary area of face (Option B): Incorrect because the maxillary division (V2), passing through foramen rotundum, supplies this region.

Loss of sensation in jaw area (Option C): Incorrect because the mandibular division (V3), not the supraorbital nerve, supplies sensation to the jaw.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with persistent high-grade fever and is found to have massive splenomegaly on examination. The spleen measures approximately 15 cm and extends diagonally from the left upper quadrant toward the right iliac fossa. Which of the following anatomical structures primarily prevents further vertical descent of the spleen?
questions.solution:
The phrenicocolic ligament is a peritoneal fold extending between the left colic flexure and the diaphragm. It forms a horizontal support and is often referred to as the "sustentaculum lienis"-that acts as a physical barrier against the downward migration of the spleen, especially in cases of massive splenomegaly.


Explanation of other options:

Lienorenal ligament (option A): Also called the splenorenal ligament, it connects the spleen to the left kidney and contains the splenic vessels and tail of the pancreas. It provides posterior support but does not prevent downward descent of the spleen.

Gastrosplenic ligament (option B): This ligament connects the stomach to the spleen and contains the short gastric arteries and left gastroepiploic artery. It mainly stabilizes the spleen anteromedially but does not prevent downward movement.

Lienophrenic ligament (option D): Also called the splenophrenic ligament, it attaches the spleen to the diaphragm and provides superior support. It prevents upward displacement, not downward movement.

Reference:

  1. [The ligament system of the spleen and its significance for surgical interventions] - PubMed
  2. Splenic Anomalies of Shape, Size, and Location: Pictorial Essay - PMC

questions.text: Which of the following structures develops from the structure marked?
questions.solution:
The marked embryological structure is the allantois, an outpouching from the hindgut involved in early urinary development. During fetal development, its lower part forms the urachus, a canal that connects the apex of the bladder to the umbilicus. After birth, this structure typically fibrosis and becomes the median umbilical ligament, which runs in the midline of the anterior abdominal wall.



Explanation of other options:

Meckel's diverticulum (Option C): This arises from the vitelline duct, not the urachus.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5838699/#:~:text

questions.text: A medical student experienced a locked jaw while yawning. Which of the following muscles, known to insert into the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint, is most likely undergoing spasmodic contraction?
questions.solution:
The lateral pterygoid muscle is the only masticatory muscle that attaches directly to the articular disc and capsule of the TMJ (via its superior head).

Lateral pterygoid:

  1. Attachment: The superior head of the lateral pterygoid inserts into the articular disc and the joint capsule, while the inferior head attaches to the neck of the mandible.
  2. Function: It helps in:
    • Depressing the mandible (opening the mouth).
    • Protrusion and lateral movements of the jaw.
  3. Spasmodic contraction: During excessive yawning, prolonged contraction of the lateral pterygoid can pull the articular disc and the mandible forward, potentially leading to jaw locking due to dislocation of the TMJ.

Explanation of other options:

Temporalis (Option B) muscle primarily elevates and retracts the mandible; it has no attachment to the articular disc.

Medial pterygoid (Option C) assists in elevation and side-to-side movements of the mandible but is not connected to the articular disc.

Masseter (Option D): A strong elevator of the mandible; also has no attachment to the articular disc.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK541027/

questions.text: A structure is marked in the image below. A defect in which of the following anatomical layers gives rise to this structure?
questions.solution:
The marked structure represents the deep inguinal ring, which is an opening in the transversalis fascia, located just above the midpoint of the inguinal ligament. This serves as the entrance to the inguinal canal, allowing the spermatic cord (in males) or round ligament of the uterus (in females) to pass through.


Transversalis Fascia:

  • The transversalis fascia is a thin connective tissue layer.
  • Lies between:
    • The deep surface of transversus abdominis
    • The extraperitoneal fat
  • It is part of the general fascia layer between the peritoneum and abdominal wall.
  • Attachments and Continuity
    • Posteriorly: Fuses with the anterior layer of thoracolumbar fascia
    • Anteriorly: Forms a continuous sheet
    • Superiorly: Blends with fascia covering the inferior surface of the diaphragm
    • Inferiorly: Continuous with iliac and pelvic parietal fasciae
  • Attachment Sites
    • Attached to:
      • Posterior margin of the inguinal ligament
      • Iliac crest (between origins of transversus abdominis and iliacus)
  • Iliopubic Tract:
    • Appears as a discrete thickening of the transversalis fascia.
  • Femoral Sheath:
    • An inferior extension of the transversalis fascia forms the anterior part of the femoral sheath.
  • Spermatic Cord and Internal Spermatic Fascia:
    • Transversalis fascia continues as the internal spermatic fascia
    • Encloses the structures that pass through the deep inguinal ring:
      • Males: Testicular vessels and ductus deferens
      • Females: Round ligament of the uterus

Explanation of other options:

Internal oblique (Option A): Forms part of the roof and posterior wall of the canal, contributes to the cremasteric muscle, but does not form the deep ring.

External oblique (Option B): Its aponeurosis forms the superficial inguinal ring and anterior wall of the inguinal canal.

Parietal peritoneum (Option C): Lies posterior to the transversalis fascia and does not form the deep ring.

questions.text: What is the result of a lesion involving Brodmann area 22?
questions.solution:
Brodmann area 22 is located in the superior temporal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere (typically the left) and corresponds to Wernicke's area. Damage to this region leads to Wernicke's aphasia, also known as receptive aphasia. Patients can speak fluently, but their speech lacks meaning and comprehension is severely impaired

Comparison of Different Types of Aphasias



Explanation of other options:

Expressive aphasia (Option A): Incorrect - This is due to Broca's area damage (Areas 44 and 45), leading to non-fluent speech with intact comprehension.

Poor repetition of language (Option C): Incorrect - Characteristic of conduction aphasia, typically due to damage to the arcuate fasciculus.

Poor naming (Option D): While present in Wernicke's aphasia, it is not unique to it; anomic aphasia is more specific for impaired naming.

Reference:

  • Aphasia
  • Conduction Aphasia

questions.text: An absent gag reflex is most likely due to a lesion in which cranial nerves?
questions.solution:
Damage to either CN IX or CN X can lead to an absent gag reflex, causing difficulty in swallowing (dysphagia) and an increased risk of aspiration.

  • The gag reflex (pharyngeal reflex) involves both the afferent and efferent limbs controlled by cranial nerves

Cranial Nerves and Reflexes:

  • Cranial nerves (CN) play a crucial role in reflexes by acting as afferent (sensory) or efferent (motor) pathways. Below is a summary of important cranial nerve-mediated reflexes:


Explanation of other options:

Cranial nerves X and VII (Option B): Incorrect - The facial nerve (VII) controls facial expression and is not part of the gag reflex.

Cranial nerves VII and V (Option C): Incorrect - These nerves are involved in facial movement and sensation, but not in the gag reflex.

Cranial nerves V and IX (Option D): Incorrect - CN V does not mediate pharyngeal motor response.

questions.text: A patient is unable to form an "O" by touching the tips of the thumb and index finger. This is most likely due to weakness of which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
• The ability to form a precise “O” shape with the thumb and index finger (tip-to-tip pinch) requires flexion of the thumb at the interphalangeal (IP) joint, which is specifically performed by the Flexor pollicis longus (FPL) muscle, innervated by the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve.
  • Flexor pollicis brevis (FPB) assists in flexion at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint of the thumb, but cannot flex the IP joint. Hence, its weakness may reduce grip strength, but it does not prevent tip-to-tip pinching.
  • In anterior interosseous nerve (AIN) palsy, FPL and the index finger's flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) are affected, leading to the inability to flex the IP joint of the thumb and DIP joint of the index finger, resulting in a flattened or abnormal "O" sign (also called pinch sign deformity).

Muscles involved in thumb movement:


Explanation of other options:

Opponens pollicis (Option A) enables opposition of the thumb, allowing it to move across the palm toward the fingers. While important for grasping, it does not flex the thumb at the IP joint, which is necessary for forming an "O"

Abductor pollicis brevis (Option B) is responsible for abducting the thumb at a right angle from the palm. It plays no role in flexing the thumb, and hence cannot contribute to the pinching motion needed to form an "O".

Flexor pollicis brevis (Option C) flexes the thumb at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint, not the interphalangeal joint. Therefore, its weakness may affect grip strength but not fine precision like tip-to-tip pinch, which requires Flexor pollicis longus.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with sciatica had tender hamstrings. Which of the following supplies a hybrid muscle that is spared in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Sciatica refers to irritation or compression of the sciatic nerve (L4-S3), which innervates most hamstring muscles.
  • However, adductor magnus is a hybrid muscle with two distinct parts and nerve supplies:
  • Adductor part is innervated by the obturator nerve (L2-L4).
  • Hamstring part is innervated by the tibial division of the sciatic nerve (L4-S3).
  • In sciatica, the tibial component is involved, potentially affecting the hamstring portion of the adductor magnus. But the adductor portion, supplied by the obturator nerve, remains unaffected.
  • Thus, the obturator nerve supplies a part of a hybrid muscle that is spared in sciatica

Hybrid Muscles and Sciatica


Explanation of other options:

Femoral nerve (Option A) innervates anterior thigh muscles like rectus femoris, not relevant to posterior thigh or sciatica.

Common peroneal nerve (Option B) supplies the short head of biceps femoris, which is part of the sciatic nerve complex and may be affected in sciatica.

Tibial nerve (Option D) forms part of the sciatic nerve, and innervates the hamstring part of adductor magnus and other posterior thigh muscles, hence it is not spared in sciatica.

questions.text: Identify the nerve marked in the given picture.
questions.solution:
The medial pectoral nerve arises from the medial cord of the brachial plexus (C8-T1). It pierces the pectoralis minor muscle and then continues to innervate the pectoralis major. This nerve typically travels through or around the axillary region, which aligns with the nerve marked in the image provided.

Nerves in the Thorax:


Explanation of other options:

Lateral pectoral nerve (Option B) also supplies the pectoralis major, but originates from the lateral cord and typically does not pierce the pectoralis minor. It approaches the pectoralis major from a more superolateral direction.

Long thoracic nerve (Option C) arises from C5-C7 roots, descends along the midaxillary line to innervate the serratus anterior. It is not involved in pectoral muscle innervation and is anatomically more lateral.

Thoracodorsal nerve (Option D) comes from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus and innervates the latissimus dorsi, a large back muscle. It does not pass through or supply the pectoral region.

Reference:

  1. Medscape - When is a modified radical mastectomy indicated

choices.text: Failure in closure of anterior neuropore of neural tube
Failure in closure of posterior neuropore of neural tube
Failure in closure of complete neural tube
Failure in closure of caudal neuropore of neural tube

questions.text: What is the embryological basis of the developmental defect shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image depicts anencephaly, a serious neural tube defect resulting from failure of the anterior (rostral) neuropore to close by around day 25 of gestation. This defect leads to absence of major portions of the brain and skull, leaving exposed neural tissue. Affected infants often present with cranial vault defects and may show feeding difficulties due to impaired neurological function.


Neural Tube Defects (NTDs) and Neuropore Closure Defects:

Explanation of other options:

Failure in closure of posterior neuropore (Option B): Incorrect because it causes spina bifida, affecting the spinal cord and vertebral column, not the brain.

Failure in closure of the complete neural tube (Option C): Incorrect because it results in craniorachischisis, a lethal defect where both the brain and spinal cord remain open.

Failure in closure of caudal neuropore (Option D): Incorrect because it leads to spina bifida occulta, a mild defect limited to the lower spine, not affecting brain development

questions.text: Identify the marked tendon in the diagram.
questions.solution:
The extensor hallucis longus (EHL) is a thin, elongated muscle located in the anterior compartment of the leg. Its tendon travels anterior to the ankle joint, passing between the tibialis anterior and extensor digitorum longus, and inserts on the distal phalanx of the great toe, enabling extension of the hallux and assisting in ankle dorsiflexion



Explanation of other options:

Flexor hallucis longus (Option B) is a posterior compartment muscle, it flexes the big toe and its tendon runs behind the medial malleolus, not the front of the ankle.

Extensor digitorum longus (Option C) extends the lateral four toes. Its tendons are lateral to the EHL tendon and do not go to the great toe.

Tibialis anterior (Option D) is located medially to EHL, it functions in dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot but does not act on the toes.

questions.text: Identify the type of joint shown in the given image.
questions.solution:
The middle radioulnar joint is a type of fibrous joint where the radius and ulna are joined by the interosseous membrane. This joint permits limited movement, allowing for efficient transmission of forces between the two bones and facilitating forearm pronation and supination. Joints like these, where bones are connected by dense connective tissue such as ligaments or membranes, are classified as syndesmosis.


Explanation of other options:

Symphysis (Option A) is a cartilaginous joint where bones are connected by fibrocartilage, such as the pubic symphysis or intervertebral discs. The middle radioulnar joint does not contain fibrocartilage.

Synchondrosis (Option C) are cartilaginous joints joined by hyaline cartilage, like growth plates or the first sternocostal joint. The radioulnar joint lacks hyaline cartilage.

Synostosis (Option D) refers to the complete fusion of bones, such as closure of skull sutures or fused epiphyseal plates, which is not the case in the middle radioulnar joint.

Reference:

  1. Types of joints

questions.text: The image shows a cross-section of the abdominal cavity. Identify the structure labeled 'A'.
questions.solution:
The descending (abdominal) aorta appears in axial sections of the abdomen as a round vascular structure located just anterior to the vertebral column and slightly to its left. It carries oxygenated blood and gives rise to several major arterial branches that supply the abdominal organs and lower limbs.

Main Arteries of the Abdomen:


  • Celiac Trunk
    • Origin: Twelfth thoracic vertebra
    • Branches: Left gastric, common hepatic, splenic arteries
    • Supplies: Foregut organs (stomach, liver, pancreas, spleen, parts of the duodenum)
  • Superior Mesenteric Artery
    • Origin: First lumbar vertebra
    • Supplies: Midgut organs (jejunum, ileum, cecum, ascending colon, proximal 2/3rd of transverse colon)
  • Inferior Mesenteric Artery
    • Origin: Third lumbar vertebra
    • Supplies: Hindgut organs (distal third of transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon, rectum, proximal anal canal)

Explanation of other options:

Superior vena cava (Option B): Not visible in the abdomen, as it lies in the thoracic cavity, draining into the right atrium from the upper body.

Inferior vena cava (Option C): Although present in the abdomen, it lies anterior and to the right of the abdominal aorta, not on the left side as shown for structure A.

Ascending aorta (Option D): Located in the thoracic cavity and gives rise to the aortic arch, it's not found in an abdominal cross-section.

choices.text: Infranuclear facial palsy on right side
Supranuclear facial palsy on left side

questions.text: A young male presents with weakness involving the lower half of the right side of his face. The angle of his mouth is drooping. He is unable to raise his eyebrows and close his eyes on both sides. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Infranuclear (lower motor neuron) lesion of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) results in complete weakness of the muscles of facial expression on the affected side, including the forehead, eyelid, and lower face.

In this case, the patient's symptoms such as drooping of the right side of the mouth, inability to close the right eye, and inability to raise the right eyebrow are consistent with right-sided LMN facial nerve palsy.

Facial Nerve Palsy:

questions.text: A boy presents with a lurching gait and dragging of his foot following a fall from a tree. Which of the labeled muscles is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
The gluteus medius muscle (label 2) plays a critical role in pelvic stabilization during walking. It functions as a hip abductor, especially during the stance phase of gait when the opposite leg is off the ground. Injury to the gluteus medius or its innervation (superior gluteal nerve, L4-S1) causes Trendelenburg gait, where the pelvis tilts downward on the contralateral side due to loss of abductor support. To compensate, the individual shifts their trunk toward the affected side producing a lurching gait.

Gluteus Muscles and Trendelenburg Gait:



Trendelenberg sign:

  • Normal Function: During single-leg stance, gluteus medius & minimus on the supporting side stabilize the pelvis by lifting the opposite (unsupported) side.
  • Positive (Uncompensated) Trendelenburg Sign:
    • Pelvic drop on the unsupported side indicates abductor mechanism failure.
    • Seen in:
      • Paralysis of gluteus medius/minimus
      • Hip dislocation (congenital/pathological)
      • Femoral neck fracture
  • Compensated Trendelenburg Gait: Patient leans toward the affected side during walking to prevent pelvic drop.
  • Bilateral Abductor Weakness:
    • Results in a waddling or duck gait.

  1. (Gluteus maximus) (Option A): Involved in hip extension. Weakness causes difficulty in rising or climbing, not lurching gait.
  2. (Piriformis) (Option C): Functions in external rotation of the hip. Piriformis syndrome causes sciatica-like pain, not abductor weakness.
  3. (Sciatic nerve) (Option D): Affects posterior thigh and lower limb, leading to foot drop and sensory loss, but not Trendelenburg gait.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK541094/

questions.text: A patient returns for their second dose of the COVID vaccine. The nurse observes that the patient's shoulder appears flat, flabby, and asymmetrical, with visible loss of the normal contour. Which structure was likely injured and could have been avoided?
questions.solution:
• The axillary nerve (C5-C6) is particularly vulnerable during deltoid intramuscular injections if administered too low or deep. It travels through the quadrangular space alongside the posterior circumflex humeral artery and supplies the deltoid and teres minor muscles.
  • Clinical Features of Axillary Nerve Injury:
    • Loss of deltoid bulk → results in a flattened shoulder and loss of shoulder contour
    • Weakness in shoulder abduction beyond 15° (deltoid dysfunction)
    • Sensory loss over the lateral upper arm (regimental badge area)
  • Prevention Tip: To avoid nerve injury, injections should be placed in the upper outer quadrant of the deltoid muscle.

Axillary Nerve Injury:



Explanation of other options:

Rotator cuff (Option A): Injury affects shoulder stability and rotation, not the contour directly.

Posterior circumflex humeral artery (Option B): While it accompanies the axillary nerve, its injury would cause bleeding or ischemia, not motor/sensory symptoms.

Lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm (Option C): Purely sensory; damage causes numbness but not motor loss or deformity.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6347325/

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17515691/

questions.text: A young child presents with hypocalcemic tetany and absent thymic shadow on imaging. Clinical evaluation reveals signs of hypoparathyroidism. Based on the developmental origin, which labeled area in the diagram of the pharyngeal pouches is likely defective?
questions.solution:
• The clinical features are characteristic of DiGeorge syndrome, a disorder due to abnormal development of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches, most commonly affecting the 3rd pouch.
  • The third pharyngeal pouch gives rise to:
    • Thymus → T-cell immunity
    • Inferior parathyroid glands → Calcium homeostasis
  • Failure of proper development leads to:
    • Thymic aplasia → T-cell immunodeficiency
    • Parathyroid hypoplasia or aplasia → Hypocalcemia and tetany
  • The fourth pouch forms the superior parathyroid glands and the ultimobranchial body (which forms C-cells of the thyroid), but it is less commonly affected.

Pharyngeal Pouch Derivatives:



DiGeorge Syndrome:

  • Cause: Deletion of 22q11.2, leading to defective neural crest migration
  • CATCH-22
    • Cardiac defects (Tetralogy of Fallot, truncus arteriosus)
    • Abnormal face
    • Thymic aplasia (T-cell immunodeficiency)
    • Cleft palate
    • Hypocalcemia (due to parathyroid agenesis)
    • 22q11.2 deletion

Explanation of other options:

1. (Option A): Forms structures in the ear; not involved in thymus/parathyroid development.

2. (Option B): Forms palatine tonsils; not involved in calcium or immune regulation.

4. (Option D): Affects superior parathyroids, but major DiGeorge defects arise from the 3rd pouch.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with difficulty flexing the distal interphalangeal joints of the 4th and 5th fingers. He is also unable to hold a piece of paper between his fingers during the Froment's test. What is the most likely site of nerve injury?
questions.solution:
The symptoms suggest ulnar nerve involvement, particularly:

  • Inability to flex the DIP joints of the ring and little fingers → due to paralysis of the medial part of flexor digitorum profundus
  • Inability to hold a paper between fingers → impaired adduction by the palmar interossei → positive Froment's sign

These muscles are supplied by the ulnar nerve, and the pattern of weakness points to a lesion proximal to the wrist, affecting both forearm and hand components. The most likely location is the cubital tunnel at the medial epicondyle, where the ulnar nerve is susceptible to compression or trauma.

Ulnar Nerve Injuries by Site:



Explanation of other options:

Shaft of Humerus (Option A): Typically affects the radial nerve, causing wrist drop, not ulnar symptoms.

Lateral Epicondyle (Option B): Involves radial nerve or common extensor origin, causing pain/weakness in wrist extension (tennis elbow).

Neck of Humerus (Option D): Involves the axillary nerve, leading to deltoid weakness and loss of sensation over the lateral shoulder.

choices.text: The superior medial quadrant has more tissue
The axillary tail of Spence crosses the anterior axillary fold
The nipple is located at the level of the fourth intercostal space in most women

questions.text: Which of the following statements about breast anatomy is correct?
questions.solution:
The axillary tail of Spence is an extension of breast tissue from the upper outer quadrant that projects into the axilla, crossing the anterior axillary fold.


Breast:

  • Contains mammary glands in the superficial fascia.
  • Extends:
    • Vertically: From the 2nd to 6th rib in the midclavicular line.
    • Horizontally: From the lateral border of the sternum to the midaxillary line along the 4th rib.
  • Suspensory ligament of Cooper:
    • Anchors the parenchyma to the overlying skin and the underlying pectoral fascia.
    • Malignant cell growth along the ligament causes dimpling of the skin.
  • Nipple:
    • The position of the nipple is variable in adult women due to differences in breast size and shape. However, in nulliparous women, it is commonly described at the level of the 4th intercostal space. (Option D)
    • Pierced by 15-20 lactiferous ducts.
  • Areola:
    • A ring of pigmented skin surrounding the nipple.

Mammary Gland:

  • A modified sweat gland.
  • Axillary tail of Spence:
    • A tail-like prolongation extending from the upper outer quadrant into the axilla.
  • Retromammary space:
    • Contains loose connective tissue, lying between the base of the gland and the deep fascia covering the mammary bed.
  • Composed of 15-20 lobes of glandular tissue separated by fibrous septa that radiate from the nipple (Option B)
  • Each lobe opens via a lactiferous duct, which enlarges to form a lactiferous sinus.

Explanation of other options:

The superior medial quadrant has more tissue (Option A): The upper outer (superolateral) quadrant of the breast contains the most glandular tissue, not the superomedial quadrant. This is also the quadrant where most breast cancers arise.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK519575/

questions.text: Which of the following is not a derivative of neural crest cells?
questions.solution:
Neural crest cells (NCCs) originate from the embryonic ectoderm and migrate to form a diverse range of tissues including:

  • Sensory and autonomic ganglia
  • Melanocytes
  • Schwann cells
  • Facial cartilage
  • Certain eye structures

However, the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) is not a neural crest derivative. It arises from the outer layer of the optic cup, which in turn develops from the neural tube-derived neuroectoderm.

Derivatives of Neural Crest Cells:

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:
questions.solution:
Corpora amylacea are small, rounded, lamellated structures commonly found in the brain (especially near ventricles and in subpial regions) and in the prostate. They are typically:

  • PAS-positive
  • Composed of glycoproteins and polysaccharides
  • Often eosinophilic or basophilic on H&E stain
  • Considered non-pathological, frequently associated with aging and chronic neurodegeneration

Corpora Amylacea:


Explanation of other options:

Corpora arenacea (Option B) also known as brain sand, these are calcified concretions seen in the pineal gland, not in the brain parenchyma or prostate.

Lewy body (Option C) are intracytoplasmic inclusions rich in α-synuclein, characteristic of Parkinson's disease and dementia with Lewy bodies. Histologically, they appear as eosinophilic spherical inclusions within neurons.

Psammoma bodies (Option D) are concentrically laminated calcifications, seen in tumors like papillary thyroid carcinoma, serous papillary ovarian carcinoma, and meningiomas. They are pathological and composed mainly of calcium.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6375970/

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6303404/

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:
questions.solution:
• The internal capsule is a key white matter structure composed of projection fibers that connect the cerebral cortex with subcortical structures such as the thalamus, brainstem, and spinal cord. It carries both:
    • Afferent fibers (sensory inputs from thalamus to cortex)
    • Efferent fibers (motor outputs from cortex to spinal cord and brainstem)
  • Anatomical Relations:
    • Medial: Caudate nucleus (anterior limb) and thalamus (posterior limb)
    • Lateral: Lentiform nucleus (putamen and globus pallidus)
  • Parts of Internal Capsule:
    • Anterior limb: Between caudate nucleus medially and lentiform nucleus
    • Posterior limb: Between thalamus medially and lentiform nucleus
    • Genu: Between anterior and posterior limb.
    • Sublentiform: Present below the lentiform.
    • Retrolentiform: Present behind lentiform.
  • Lesion of Internal Capsule:
    • Occurs due to hemorrhage, leading to spastic paralysis (due to involvement of pyramidal and extrapyramidal fibers for the upper limb, trunk, and lower limb) and loss of sensations in the opposite half of the body.
    • Most commonly involved artery - Charcot's artery of cerebral hemorrhage (striate branches from middle cerebral artery).
    • Lesions in the sublentiform and retrolentiform parts of the internal capsule lead to visual loss and auditory defects.

Explanation of other options:

Body of fornix (Option B): A white matter tract connecting hippocampus to mammillary bodies; located superior to the thalamus and not between major basal nuclei.

Globus pallidus (Option C): A component of the lentiform nucleus; lies lateral to the internal capsule.

Lateral ventricle (Option D): A fluid-filled cavity lined by ependyma; appears as a dark CSF-filled space on imaging, not a compact bundle like the internal capsule.

questions.text: Identify the marked area in the image:
questions.solution:
The Pouch of Douglas, also called the rectouterine pouch, is the lowest point of the peritoneal cavity in females when in an upright position. It is located between the posterior surface of the uterus and the anterior surface of the rectum.

This space is clinically important as it can collect fluid in conditions like:

  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Ruptured ectopic pregnancy
  • Ascites or hemoperitoneum

Rectouterine pouch (Pouch of Douglas):

  • Pouch between rectum posteriorly and uterus anteriorly
  • Most dependent part of abdominal cavity in standing
  • Most dependent part of the abdomen in lying down position is hepatorenal pouch of Morrison

Explanation of other options:

Morrison's pouch (Option A), also known as the hepatorenal recess, located between the liver and right kidney. It's the most dependent peritoneal space in supine position, not in the pelvis.

Vesicouterine pouch (Option B) lies between the bladder and uterus; located anterior to the uterus, not posterior like the Pouch of Douglas.

Ischioanal Fossa (Option D): A fat-filled space on either side of the anal canal, below the pelvic diaphragm, involved in allowing expansion of the anal canal during defecation. It's not part of the peritoneal cavity.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5537103/

questions.text: Which of the following is the first structure formed by migration of epiblast cells through the primitive streak?
questions.solution:
During gastrulation, epiblast cells migrate through the primitive streak to form the three germ layers.

  • The first migrating cells move inward and displace the hypoblast, giving rise to the definitive endoderm.
  • The next wave forms the intraembryonic mesoderm.
  • Epiblast cells that do not migrate remain as the ectoderm.

Gastrulation and Germ Layer Formation



Explanation of other options:

Cardiac mesoderm (Option B): Derived from mesoderm, which forms after endoderm.

Epidermis (Option C): Ectodermal in origin; ectoderm forms after migration is complete.

Neural groove (Option D): A product of ectodermal folding during neurulation, well after germ layer formation.
